title: Will the U.S. consume more energy from renewable sources in May 2021 than it did in May 2019, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)?
preds:
Pandemic has shifted the production of electricity from coal to renewable sources and these topped coal for straight 40 days till the first week of May 2021.
https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/renewable/amid-pandemic-u-s-renewable-power-sources-have-topped-coal-for-40-days/75545488.
Hence, I believe the consumption will exceed.

January was 0.98 vs 1.05 projected. They're now projecting 1.14 for May vs 1.13 previously.  May 2019 was 1.06. So this still looks likely, but the miss in January and the uncertainty associated with the economic recovery makes me cautious so I'm maintaining at 85%. Links and previous projections at my previous comment here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1244606
probably, but I think the crowd is overconfident.

A little pre-mortem: the general trend is slightly upwards, but the variations over the year are quite big. May numbers have been growing for years, BUT from 2019 to 2020 they went down (less overall energy consumption due to Covid-19). The most recent month we have data about, January 2021, was very close to pre-pandemic January 2020. In 2020 that base was not enough to go above the previous year´s May number. And May 2019 still is the record-holder, only May and June 2020 came close. Overall energy use will be higher this year than in 2020, but will it be so much higher than 2019? And will the renewables be more (and of those: Biomass as the biggest single factor)? Most probably yes, but not 98%.
They asked this question with a reason, and it was NOT to give everybody a safe 0.0 Brier for it. If this resolves as "no" (and that is definitely possible), lots of people will feel the joy of something close to 2.0.
Next release is today, if it's on track with their forecast I'll likely go up.

The overall trend is certainly upwards, however there will be some natural variation based on both supply (wind strength, cloud cover, etc.) and demand of renewables. The table below shows the monthly figures from the data source, the final column = 1 if there was an increase on the figure from 24 months before, =0 if decrease on 24 months prior. Within the last 3 years, it's been higher in 33 out of 36 months (including a few corrections for months during lockdown). This gives us a base % of 92%. Month	Btu	Increase	>0?
2018 February	0.892018	4%	1
2018 March	0.995847	7%	1
2018 April	1.001285	13%	1
2018 May	1.040062	16%	1
2018 June	1.014579	19%	1
2018 July	0.92831	6%	1
2018 August	0.934291	14%	1
2018 September	0.845146	7%	1
2018 October	0.883569	6%	1
2018 November	0.88736	7%	1
2018 December	0.925153	-1%	0
….			
2020 October	0.920819	4%	1
2020 November	0.977808	10%	1
2020 December	0.987838	7%	1
2021 January	0.976373	6%	1

More large corporations and cities are committing to using renewables, and going to netzero by 2030. In addition, because of the pandemic there is pent up demand for manufacturing and transportation that has already seen major upticks in March and April.

I never thought I'd see the day when at the end of a long week I'd kick back and wind down to the soothing mindlessness of building ugly excel spreadsheets.
I should've done this sooner, but oh well, here is what I learned.... In general, the YoY deltas (and MoM for that matter) are, at this point largely random. That is to say, I'm sure a super computer with access to more data would find a correlation here to the color of the president's tie or the weather. 
In general, I feel we, the crowd, are over-confident... however, not necessarily wrong. I assembled the following facts as a statistical curiosity. A YoY drop occurs 17-25% of the time, not insignificant, but on average, the May annual delta is 2-4% (in the black.) Total Months: 576	
MoM Drops: 287	or 49.8%
YoY Drops: 141 or 24.5%
Avg. May Delta: 2.6%

Last Decade		
Months: 121	
MoM Drop: 62 or 51.2%
YoY Drops: 21 or 17.4%
Avg. May Delta: 3.8%
The trend continues to show growth in renewable energy consumed.
Sorry, this is not 98%. In May 2020 it was lower than in May 2019. The general trend might be slightly upwards, but I think, the crowd is overconfident on this one.
If you want to go down the rabbit hole, here's the entrance. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1253610

I've lowered my forecast slightly due to predictions of continued drought. Low hydro numbers could be a killer here, but I'm yet to figure out how to quantify it. Does anyone have any ideas?
@cafebedouin @Okanaganopolis
Looks like it is still going up.

-5 for now. I found some info that could be useful for later. This shows the EIA's short term projections on energy: https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/data/browser/#/?v=3&f=M&&start=201701&end=202212&linechart=TETCFUEL~RETCBUS&ctype=linechart&maptype=0&id=&map= Currently they're forecasting 1.13 for May 2021, which would exceed. But it'll be interesting to compare the forecasts to actual, because so far the end of 2020 remains down in energy consumption relative to 2019. So it will depend how quickly the economy and energy production recovers in 2021 I think. https://www.eia.gov/totalenergy/data/browser/index.php?tbl=T01.01#/?f=M&start=200306&end=202011&charted=14 Tracking for later comparison in the coming months. Line 1 is EIA total energy consumption projections. Line 2 is EIA renewable energy consumption projections. Dec |Jan  |Feb |Mar|Apr |May
8.51|8.81|7.74|8.06|7.22|7.45
1.00|1.05|0.99|1.10|1.07|1.13 If we're falling short of those numbers with the next releases I'll likely revise downward.

Over the last 8 years, the share of renewables in the total energy market ranges between 12-13%, which is almost constant.  This can be attributed to the fact there is no national renewable energy policy in the US. This may change as the US is set to join the Paris Climate Accord. As per Deloitte, the government is planning to spend 2 trillion dollars in clean energy. These efforts will increase the composition of renewable in the total energy consumption.
Okay, after looking at the numbers the crowd is right. Renewable use increased even in 2008 during the recession. So our coming economic downturn is not likely to affect this.
May 2021 economy will be significantly less than May 2019 economy.

Initial forecast. I think this question is really a proxy question asking about what the economy is going to do in 2021 compared to 2019. if the economy is roughly the same or better than it was in 2019, then renewables will increase. If the economy is significantly worse than 2019 then renewables will decrease. my estimation is that the economy will be significantly worse in 2021 than 2019. I will try to crunch the numbers on the actual renewables in a day or two and then revise.
Not so sure anymore. Trend is not looking very good
the Crowd is more and more fort YES
Uh... line go up? My forecast here is pretty simple based on the chart, renewables have been rising steadily and are only getting cheaper and more widely deployed.
allowing for more sever damage to the infra structure for clean energy transmission...
Under this administration especially, I think that renewable energy consumption will bounce back to be higher than May 2019.

I actually doubt there are any signs of COVID contraction in renewables consumption. If energy consumption contracts, most renewables do not contract as they are often 0 variable cost. However, I will put it at 97% instead of the 98% which I think represents a no COVID scenario as half the renewables is NOT 0 variable cost.

The long-term trend in renewable energy consumption is upwards. Although May 2019 was the all time high, the difference between May 2019 and 2020 is only about 2%. Very likely that considering the lower levels of lockdowns and higher economic activity, the consumption will be higher.
The pandemic restrictions has reduced the energy consumption drastically.

may 2019: 1.052799 ;may 2020: 1.037801 mar-oct 2019: 0.978191/1.013433/1.052799/0.987871/0.97349/0.928977/ 0.890114/ 0.920677
mar-oct-2020: 0.963422/0.909513/1.037801/1.043584/0.997849/0.952372/ 0.883232 / 0.929689 consumption in 2020 is higher than in 2019 only for the months of June/July/August, possibly due to weather conditions.
As the consumption in May 2019 was exceptionally high, the probability of this happening again does not seem to me to be maximum. But a lot of forecaster since the opposite, the consensus is strong
and see the initial rational of @Forcaster  (source: https://www.eia.gov/totalenergy/data/browser/index.php?tbl=T01.03)

Southwest Power Pool recently announced that wind is their largest source of energy now.  As the new wind installed at end of 2020, for PTC purposes, comes to full output in 2021, should be able to be 2020 with little difficulty.  Also, biogas should start making a come back with some slow improvement in economic activity.
Updated to reflect the increase in recent production. I will keep away from absolute certainty because of the cyclical trends which depends on the climate.
Our usage of energy has increased no doubt but maybe we increased our usage of fossil fuels

After looking through multiple official sources such U.S. Energy Information administration I see a pattern between all of them that renewable energy is going up overall and public opinion is favorable towards it as well. Not only that but the new administration favors expanding renewable energy. I can only see consumption going down if there is a major event that shifts public perception of renewable energy.
Southwest Power Pool, which has one of the largest amounts of wind generation in the country, recently announced a record year for wind generation in 2020.
Updating to go with the crowd since the website never updates.

Using a very modest increase for wind, and larger increase for solar generation (starting point May 2020), holding others constant, it looks more likely to happen.  Wind should see a much larger increase for the calendar year 2020, but a big chunk is at the end of the year, so wait and see.

I am actually deciding to update my forecast quite a bit. This was inspired by a comment below. Basically I looked for those times in the recent past where May year N was lower than May year N-2 and found this to happen in 2019 and in 2015. However, I now realize I should remove 2019 from the equation as that was influenced by COVID. That leaves only 2015 and in that case 2013 May consumption was more than 13% above the 2013 average monthly consumption, while 2015 was only 3% above the 2013 monthly average. This means that since 2019 May consumption was 12% above the 2019 monthly average, we would need to see the 2021 May consumption again only 3-4% above the 2021 monthly average, something that might only happen 2 out of 100 years or so. This would lead me to 98%, however, I think May 2021 might see some small contraction due to COVID so I will tamper this down to 96%.

@balzac Just spotted your comment and that you're the propagator of it. Cool. (get it?) I'm joining the question late.  1. First observation: the Question above cites May 2019, consumption of *1.059944* quadrillion Btus . But the May 2019 numbers I see on the website chart today read: *1.052799*. ..... A tiny (.01%) but notable difference in the datasets I see vs. the one the question provides.
2. Re my familiarity with Lumber business. It doesn't translate to the biomass/energy side, I'm afraid, so my advice is anecdotal only. You've been warned. 
3. Wood biomass is rarely of processed for transport ethanol, it's burned for heat. 
4. Unlike the "free" fuel of Solar and Wind, wood biomass has extraction/processing costs and competes with other burnables to be least bad at best cost. Competition for record-high value Lumber constrains lower value biomass stocks to only the waste. In low lumber markets, more fibre's directable to biomass. not today.  Could electricity from "free" renewables increase in availability (hence use) YoY 2019/21? Probably.  The point that corn (ethanol) use is more dependent on driving/transport is noted. I feel driving will NOT replicate May 2019 in May 2021. That's the counterpoint.

Per other forecasters, do need to factor in demand...if for example Covid (or something else) sinks demand possible this won’t be resolved as “yes”. The trend is inexorably ascending. I live within 100km of a wind farm and while imperfect, better than status quo. 
Following video is free (believe WSJ’s videos are free).
https://www.wsj.com/video/more-money-is-flowing-into-green-energy-than-ever-before-heres-why/B227310D-5972-4B82-BD81-33E09FCFCECC.html

This one is a bit tricky. If we remove 2020 from the mix as an outlier then the trend line on renewable consumption is certainly in an upward trajectory. We have seen pretty steady increases in the May consumption number from 2015-2019 (rising from 0.289 Quadtrillion BTU to 1.052 Quadtrillion BTU). The increase in consumption has also been met by an increase in capacity, which should indicate the energy market is able to meet the pace of growth. 32 GW of new utility-scale solar and wind came online in 2020, which accounted for about 75% of the growth in new electricity capacity. A bulk of the capacity was due to come online in December, which should help the 2021 numbers rebound a bit. Obviouly, the elephant in the room is demand heading into the first half of 2021. If COVID restritions continue it is likely that we continue to see decreases in commercial and industrical demand and increases in residential  demand. This is what helped spur the dropoff in May 2020 number compared to May 2019. Given we will need time for a vaccine rollout before we see increase commerial and industrial demand, I am tampering down my expections for the May 2021 numbers until we see more data in early 2021.
This trend is going nowhere but up!

I have decided to temper my assessment until I see some data on how the new wind and solar effect the numbers. I still believe it is going to be difficult for May 2021 to exceed the highest total renewable use in May in the last 10 years though, especially since COVID will still be a factor.

Outside view: since 2002, number of Mays that have positive total renewable energy consumption growth from 2 years ago: 15 / 17 total years = 88% base rate.  Inside view: 
New renewable capacity additions: "Electricity generation from renewable energy sources rises from 18% in 2019 to 20% in 2020 and to 21% in 2021. EIA forecasts that planned additions to wind and solar generating capacity in 2020 and 2021 will contribute to increasing electricity generation from those sources. EIA expects the U.S. electric power sector will add 23.0 gigawatts (GW) of new wind capacity in 2020 and 9.5 GW of new capacity in 2021. Expected utility-scale solar capacity rises by 12.8 GW in 2020 and by 14.0 GW in 2021." [1] "In the first three quarters of 2020, renewable energy — almost entirely solar and wind energy — accounted for 70% of new US power capacity." [5] Dip in total electricity consumption due to COVID: "EIA forecasts that consumption of electricity in the United States will decrease by 3.9% in 2020. EIA forecasts total U.S. electricity consumption will rise by 1.3% in 2021." [1] However, even with lower overall electricity consumption in June, July, August 2020, renewable consumption was up YoY for those months, showing that renewable energy consumption can grow even with reduced overall consumption. Given EIA forecasts overall electricity consumption growth in 2021, then renewables are likely to grow as well.  Correlation with GDP: Q2 with -31% and Q3 with +33%, which correlates with renewable energy consumption growth (negative in March, April, May; positive in June, July, August). GDP forecasts [3] and [4] present all the various scenarios and factors going forward, so it is highly uncertain, but hopefully by Q2 2021 the economy and country is recovering with roll-out of the vaccine and warmer weather. Overall: given the tons of new renewable installations, the robust nature of renewable energy consumption to rise even if total energy consumption is down, and the forecast for GDP growth in 2021, I will increase base rate of 88% to 94%.  Future updates: continue to monitor monthly updates on EIA, GDP growth and forecasts.  [1] https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/
[2] https://www.bea.gov/news/2020/gross-domestic-product-third-quarter-2020-advance-estimate
[3] https://conference-board.org/research/us-forecast#:~:text=This%20results%20in%20an%20annual,3.2%20percent%20growth%20in%202021.&text=This%20upside%20forecast%20results%20in,of%206.9%20percent%20in%202021.
[4] https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/insights/economy/us-economic-forecast/united-states-outlook-analysis.html
[5] https://cleantechnica.com/2020/11/30/renewables-70-of-new-us-power-capacity-in-2020-solar-43/

Looks like the trend is clearly upward and renewable energy seems likely to continue increasing in the future. May looks to be the annual peak but it doesn't look like May 2019 was exceptionally high to make this more unlikely.
Heavy investment into renewables. Heavy investment out of fossil fuels. Democrat as President who has a heavy interest in the environment.

Large increase in new wind capacity in 2020, confirmed by EIA.  Biomass appears to be wildcard and suffered the most out of renewables from Covid-19, but even with no Biomass rebound, wind and solar new generation should offset.

The power grid operational plans work off decade long timelines. Less than a year of trouble is of little concern to long-term upgrade plans -- meaning more green energy has been installed this year and is given preference over coal/gas/oil turbines as solar/wind "fuel" is free. Why use a consumable asset when you have one running all the time? We're not at a point where we care to just decommission entire energy farms. Political pressure still hasn't let up -- save the planet, etc. Tech pressure -- we need alternative energies. We want alt energies. Innovation today will drive tomorrow's economies. As we inch closer to truly colonizing/mining our solar system, we need sources of energy that can be found throughout the universe. The whole oil needing organic life to form problem is a real bummer off Earth. (I admit this bit is irrelevant in the near future but I like my soap box). And need I mention the projected energy demands? There's a reason the country is perpetually short on anything with the word "electrical" in its job title and largely outdated energy facilities are still running.

Thanks to the generosity and relevance of the comment from @Cjsb1024, and clarification from @Econja2018
I review my perception From 16% to 85 %
In posting a reply to a question, I am convincing myself that it is becoming ore certain.

All my perception about this question is about how bad the covid-19 will affect the consumption of energy.
Sadly, the United States, will  be hardly affect in the next months. The US economy will be affected so the energy consumption too... so renewable too. The Covid-19 have plummeted the revenu of the Hydro-Quebec... second quarter of 2020. The demand seem to be relate to energy consumption. (A lockdown in Quebec seemed to be very severe in regard of what i saw in US. Biden administration, maybe, will take some kind of measure like others countries did, vaccine will not be a a sufficient variable in the time frame. Extract from the QUARTERLY NEWSLETTER
Third Quarter 2020
"On markets outside Québec, Hydro-Québec Production’s net electricity exports decreased by $151 million to total $1,004 million. This is due to the impact of
temperatures in the first quarter, which resulted in lower demand and prices on export markets, as well as to the repercussions of the global pandemic, which also
led to lower prices and market requirements, especially in the second quarter. "
https://www.hydroquebec.com/data/documents-donnees/pdf/quarterly-report-ceo.pdf?v=2020111

While May 2019 was better than April 2019, it was also higher than May 2018 by about 1 percent. 
May 2021 should see an increase in energy uses from all sources, renewables included as the economy slowly recovers.
The data I found for 2019 did not agree with the figure shown above.

2019 February	873.434
2019 March	990.413

2019 June	1000.405

Looks like 10-20% increase in total wind capacity by end of year 2020 (EIA, AWEA).  Wind does not need new demand growth (covid unlikely to impact usage), it just needs an RPS and to displace retiring coal plants.  Oh, and windy weather.

I want to promote this question since I am credited with asking it. I actually asked a slightly  different question, but that's neither here nor there.  I asked this question because it is the sort of thing we should know if we care about alternative energy. It caused me to dig deep and the answer I uncovered is ironic be

The pressure to decarbonize is growing and both the EU and Biden administrations will push renewables through multiple channels. In US look for the growing military support for treating climate as a national security issue
Low energy prices forcing more coal retirements.

Strikes me that Renewables Consumption for May 2020 would have surpassed May 2019 but for the pandemic:  2019-2020 YOY Change for May:
Hydro: ~0
Geothermal: ~o
Solar: + 3%
Wind: + 2%
Biomass: -6%
Total Renewables: -2% In other words, biomass accounted for more than all the decline. Less driving -> less ethanol consumption.  See THIS ONE CHART: https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=PET&s=MGFUPUS1&f=M But driving is back, baby.  Both solar and wind have made steady YOY gains for the past 5+ years, while hydro has been stable and geothermal negligible.  I don’t see what factor could account for total renewables consumption in May 2021 being less than May 2019. Meteor?

I know I am different from the crowd, but historically the May 2019 use of renewable sources was the second highest it has been in the last 10 years, with only 2018 being a bit higher, and it seems to be trending down not up. It takes time for new policies to take effect, so I do not see it going above the second highest amount used in the last 10 years.

In 2020, Renewable energy usage has been below 2018 level in month of March, April & May. I believe this was due to shelter in place caused by covid. In all other months, the consumption has been substantially above 2018 level.
The resources to generate renewable energy are fixed and their energy product will be the first to use as it cannot be dialed down as a gas or coal generator can be.

Predicts that there will not be a vaccine by May 2021 and that a large portion of the population will still be spending an above-average amount of time at home, resulting in higher energy consumption.

I will come back to this later. 90% is simply the average of how often any month exceeded the same month 2 years ago in recent years. What is not captured here is whether May 2019 had above average production, e.g. due to much sunnier or windier weather than usual. If so, the chance would need to be lower than the historical average. I will perform this analysis later and update this forecast.
All trends point this way, and Biden will really push for this as well.
An article on latest capacity addition statistics:  https://cleantechnica.com/2020/11/30/renewables-70-of-new-us-power-capacity-in-2020-solar-43/
Economy and people will be recovering from pandemic, and using more non-renewable energy resources. Renewable resources can't meet demand.
99.6%. Latest monthlies are up by healthy margin versus two years ago. With vaccine rolling out, Covid should no longer be a factor

More wind and solar capacity has been added in 2020. This implies more renewables by May 2021. However, since wind and solar are dependent on wind speed and solar irradiation, a May 2021 with consistently lower wind speeds and/or high cloud cover may lead to less generation. Also, some of the new capacity are behind transmission bottlenecks and may not be able to generate at capacity.
Shale is being shut down/disposed of by majors so by default the proportion for renewables will rise
Covid 19 impacts on primarily travel will continue through 2021.
The movements of clean enery and sustanibility in diverse industries are growing in all USA this makes pressure to adopt clean energies with more enthusiasm

Triple exponential smoothing forecast on the years through 2000 to 2020, for which the linear trend in the data looks stable after adjusting for seasonality, gives %65.3 as the odds under the usual assumptions of independence and normality. Possibly some adjustment is needed for the political situation to this base forecast, but the correlation is not striking enough in the data to warrant such a correction, so I will just go with the base rate.
Spring will be colder in the US than in 2019, thus more "indoor" time.

Between May 2009 and May 2020, the amount of renewable energy consumed by the US (according to the EIA) has dropped four times (.364) and has only dropped in two consecutive years once (.17).  Therefore I will set a base rate of renewable energy consumption increase at .75, right between .83 and .64...  The last time renewable consumption dropped twice in a row, it was coincident with falling oil prices in 2014-2015.  Oil prices are too low to fall as drastically again before May 2021.  Furthermore, when the US joined the Paris Accords in 2016 it was coincident with a steady rise in year on year consumption of renewable energy.  I anticipate a neutral to positive impact on renewable consumption based on Pres-Elect Biden's assertion that he will rejoin the accords upon inauguration in January. Finally, a more thorough analysis would require looking at the amount of increase each year since we will compare May of 2021 to May of 2019... a year on year increase is possible that does not exceed the renewable consumption in May of 2019.  The analysis above may reveal that the consumption is likely to increase but not at a volume sufficient to make May 2021 greater than May 2019.

-80 Atm only 4% of US-Americans are positive of Corona with maybe +2% not detected. Means the big wave will hit US in the future. Biden will force lock downs which will cause a reduction in the overall energy consume. I think, with vaccine it will last till March or April to get Covid under control in US. This will not left enough time to recover the energy consume to a level of 2019. Biden and Kerry are pro renewable but it will take more time to get this into account then may 2021. Weather could be a point. If extreme hot or extreme cold.
Saying yes as Baseline w/o research...

Some key things to note 
Wind energy is the fastest growing of all the renewable sources(now the largest source 24% of renewable energy) and primarily because of tax credit support. Wind capacities come up typically in the 4th quarter to claim credit(almost 40% of year`s capacity comes online in December). This year is also expected to be the last year for claiming credits on  wind capacities as a result this year is expected to see a record number of windpower generation capacities come online.
Wind generation is typically the greatest during the spring and fall(refer link)
https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=42955
https://oilprice.com/Alternative-Energy/Wind-Power/US-Wind-Capacity-Additions-Set-To-Surge-To-Record-In-2020.html Even in May 20 we just saw a 1.7% YoY dip in the renewable energy production even though overall electricity consumption declined by 14%.
With all those capacities coming onstream by the end of this year. Probability of a dip in the consumption from renewable sources is highly unlikely
Production capacity is rising and many big users have made plans to sh8ft which is driving availability. Incoming government will help, not hinder, expansion.

Note to self: 
1.059 Quadrillion BTUs May 2019
1.041 " " May 2020 I think we are being aggressive as a crowd... I may revise down once the dust settles some.

Almost certainly yes: it's more difficult to take renewable capacity offline than other generation sources. So far the covid isn't reducing consumption from renewable sources in the trend. With a COVID vaccine increasing demand and a likely Biden administration subsidizing renewable capacity, I expect there are other sources of upwards pressure.

May is peak renewable, and looking at the numbers form the last couple years (1) it's likely there will only be a small shift in summer generating capacity coming into 2021, the section "Future projections" on the wiki summary (an IEA reference) suggests the forecast is for "277.77 gigawatts of renewable available by 2024 up 23.1% from 2018", but this is only up 7.2% in total from 2020, an average of ~1.6% growth YoY over the next 4 years.  We can assume this growth will come from Solar and Wind generation, but if you consider the fact that power consumption drops during lockdowns and creeps, rather than jumps back, up (2), there is a reasonable chance this will resolve as a 'no'.  1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_the_United_States#Future_projections
2. https://www.iea.org/reports/covid-19-impact-on-electricity
Yes, simply because more energy from renewable sources is available.

The question asks about total usage of renewable energy. The US economy will not have recovered from covid by May 2021. This means total energy usage will be lower than it was in May 2019. In addition, the new US president will be under great pressure to stimulate the economy at all costs, which means pressure on exploiting the US reserves of fossil fuels and deregulation, leaving renewable energy behind. So the probability that renewable energy usage will be greater in May 2021 is quite small.

Renewables have made significant inroads into the use of fossil fuels like coal. That is an established trend that is unlikely to slow. In addition there's a great deal of talk about economic stimuli centered on the 'green economy'.

Renewables will become cheaper, and Biden will push them. However, overall energy consumption way be down due to Corona and economic downturn, and weather conditions also influence renewable's share, hence not 100%

Economy will still be recovering through Q3 of FY21. May 2019 was the height of economic activity prior to the pandemic. Proposed investments in renewables have been slowed due to decreased industrial activity and impact of tariffs on Chinese imports of solar components. Biden administration plan will take time to implement.
I re-read the question and changed this forecast.

Going to leave my analysis here marginally anecdotal for the sake of time. Given the 2-year prior nature to the question and the fact that such a 2-year Month-Month comparison appears to nearly always (I believe some others have assessed this at 80+%) proven true, my default will be to the 80% yes category. Adjusting from there for known major solar projects that are supposed to come online around that timeline/came online this year (see links below, 6.5MW in Nebraska, 20MW in Kansas, etc) I'm pushing that to 95% yes Nebraska Solar Farms Coming online in late 2020: https://www.sunvest.com/press-release/nebraska-is-embracing-solar-by-welcoming-three-more-solar-farms/#:~:text=%5BPewaukee%2C%20Wisc.%2C%20February,miles%20west%20of%20Madison%20County.
Kansas Solar Farm that came online earlier this year: https://www.sunflower.net/largest-solar-farm-in-kansas-starts-commercial-operation/

Back of the envelope guess is 85% in favor of May 2021 exceeding May 2019. My main underlying assumptions and best guess are below: 1) Energy Production: is the grid increasingly powered by renewables? Guess yes
2) Energy deployments: Are deployments of renewable energy increasing? Guess yes.
3) Consumption rates: Has energy consumption decreased significantly? Covid-19 is suppressing energy demand from commercial entities.
4) Economic concerns: Are energy prices consistent?  Yes, prices are stable. 
5) Macro-economic concern: Can most Americans pay their energy bills? Yes, but their are macroeconomic headwinds due to a failure to pass a new stimulus.

Undecided as of right now, but it looks as though it has been lower on average than 1.05. I am going to say that it is not going to beat the high number for the last 5 years. However, if the new administration pushes for change to renewable energy use in the first few months, it could change my opinion. Changes in policy take time to implement usually, so I do not foresee it changing significantly in only a few months.

Misread the question. Turns out we are looking for a 2 year change.
If we look at a sample of the last 24 months and compare the Total renewables generated to their values two years prior we get:
- Last 24 months: 4 months showed lower generation than 2 years prior => Yes = 83%
- Last 12 Months: 2 months showed lower generation than 2 years prior => Yes = 83%
In the past, 17% of the time the values were not larger than the same month 2 years prior.
My base rate will be Yes=83% for now. This will require additional research into any major projects that were done, that could affect generation from renewables.

I looked at the last 24 months of the "Total Renewable Energy" consumed and compared each value to the one the year before.
That value was larger than the year before: 
- 15 out of 24 months for the last 24 months (Yes = 63%)
- 8 out of 12 months for the last 12 months (Yes = 66%) So I am starting with my base prediction to be the average of 65%=Yes.

Total has gone up every year according to charts, even with consumption down in 2020. Infrastructure for renewable energy is in place at minimal extra cost.  The key element would be the ethanol additive to the gas, but as a first estimate, I am all in.

Renewable energy is on the rise and has been for some time. It has risen every year in May since 2015 until covid. However, covid is still around and according to a few articles I read, companies are holding off on going 100% renewable until they can predict the demands of the market better. We just set a record for cases over a week but also got good news on a potential vaccine. Even with covid the drop from May 2019 to May 2020 was not that steep and still remained over May 2018 levels. I think an incoming Biden admin will work to grant incentives to more companies that go 100% renewable, however it rose similarly in a Trump admin as an Obama one. I think there will be less covid uncertainty than in May 2020, but not enough certainty to beat May 2019 numbers. I will put it at 35% and revise monthly with new covid information.
Initial forecast without research. I believe intuitively that a Biden/Harris administration will push renewables more than Trump.
US renewable energy production has doubled since 2008 and the rate of change is accelerating

Electricity generation from renewable energy sources rose from 18% in 2019 to 20% in 2020 and forecasted to 22% in 2021. The increase in renewables' share is the result of planned additions to wind and solar generating capacity.
Trend line is up, but 2020 is not shown.  So guessing that it is flat to 2019.  Hydro is cheap and fllws always, sun and wind are subsidized by PTC. If not, then I am revisiting this forecast.

Since this is not specific as to how much more it seems certain that the  trend line is moving steadily upward on renewable energy.  The new administration should maintain or increase that trend in the future.

The US continues to invest in renewable energies and that will increase the supply.  Consumption is insatiable and with the prospects of continued global warming and higher temperatures, electric cars increasingly available, and bans on other energy sources (such as no natural gas in San Francisco), the need for power will go up.
